Paper: E.L. Forget. The town with no poverty: The health effects of a Canadian Guaranteed Annual Income Field Experiment. Canadian Public Policy, 37 (3), 283-306. 2011.
Summary of findings: A Canadian guaranteed annual income field experiement from 1974 to 1979 resulted in an 8.5 percent reduction in hospitalization rates and reduced contacts with physicians, showing that a relatively modest guaranteed annual income can improve population health and bring significant health system savings.
Nature of Cash Transfer: A guaranteed annual income: Familities with no income will receive 60% of Statistics Canada low-income cut-off, varying by family size, degree of benefits received from other sources, and cost of living. People who did not qualify for welfare previously saw largest increases in income.
Relevance: Effects on population health, reflected in economic and psychological outcomes

Paper: E. L. Forget, A. Peden, S. Strobel. Cash Transfers, Basic Income and Community Building. Social Inclusion, 1(2), 84–91. September 2013.
Summary of findings: Various theories suggest that cash transfers not only affect individual decision-making but also impacts how households interact within a community, hence it is important to understand the social impact of basic income when addressing questions of how best to design cash transfer schemes.
Relevance: Spillover effects of UBI

Paper: A. Goodman-Bacon, L. McGranahan. How Do EITC Recipients Spend Their Refunds? Economic Perspectives, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, 32(Q2). 2008.
Summary of findings: Recipients of the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), a U.S. tax credit scheme that distributes a large transfer to low-income households once a  year, concentrated most of their household spending in vehicle purchases and transportation spending in response to their EITC payments.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC): a tax credit that serves to offset the payroll taxes and supplement the wages of low-income workers, with payments concentrated in February and March when tax refunds are received.
Relevance: Economic effects, measurement and tracking of consumption by category

Paper: Johannes Haushofer, Jeremy Shapiro. Household Responses to Income Changes: Evidence from an Unconditional Cash Transfer Program in Kenya. 2013.
Summary of findings: Unconditional cash transfers in Kenya led to a rise in food, medical and education expenditures and a fall in expenditures on alcohol and tabacco. Households likely face savings constraints, since one-off lump-sum transfers tended to be spent on durables. Cash transfers resulted in large increases in the receipients' psychological well-being as well.
Nature of Cash Transfer: RCT:  Selection of treatment group was randomized at both the village and household levels; further, within the treatment group, recipient gender (wife vs. husband), transfer timing (lump-sum vs monthly installments over 9 months), and transfer magnitude (USD 404 vs. USD 1,520) were randomized
Useful Tools: Surveys on consumption, asset holdings, employments, education, health, food security, female empowerment, and psychological well-being.
Relevance: Economic, Health, Employment, Social, Educational Effects

Paper: Rigmar Osterkamp. The Basic Income Grant Pilot Project in Namibia: A Critical Assessment. Basic Income Studies. 2013.
Summary of findings: A study involving the distribution of a monthly basic income grant (BIG) of NAD100 to around 1000 citizens had inadequate research methods and hence could not address questions about basic income related to political decision making purposes.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Basic Income Grant of NAD 100 (about USD 15) paid to around 1000 citizens in a Namibian village.
Relevance: Research design for political decision-making

Paper: David A Cook, Thomas J Beckman. Concepts in Validity and Reliability for Psychometric Instruments: Theory and Application. The American Journal of Medicine. 2006.
Summary of findings: Clear understanding of validity and reliability in psychometric assessment is essential for practitioners in diverse medical settings. This article discusses five sources for assessing construct validity and five sources for assessing reliability and its related statistical measures.
Relevance: Validity and realibility of surveys

Paper: Marketing Research and Information Systems: Questionnaire Design. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. 1997.
Summary of findings: This document serves as a guide to designing surveys and questionaires for a range of purposes, and addresses all aspects one should look at when conducting surveys, from reaching targeted respondents to deciding on question content and wording.
Relevance: Guide to designing surveys/questionnaires

Paper: Francesa Bastagli, Jessica Hagen-Zanker, Luke Harman, Valentina Barca, Georgina Sturge and Tanja Schmidt, Luca Pallerano. Cash Transfers: What Does the Evidence Say? A rigorous review of programme impact and the role of design and implementation features. Overseas Development
Summary of findings: Cash transfers are linked to reductions in monetary poverty, increases in total and food expenditure, increases in school attendance, increases in the uptake of health services, and increases in savings, livestock and agricultural ownership. The effect of cash transfers on employment outcomes remains unclear. Higher transfer levels are associated with larger impacts. Longer duration of exposure to cash transfers are linked to greater improvements in outcomes. Cash transfers conditional on certain behaviors more positively affect the outcome related to the behavior than in unconditional cash transfers.
Nature of Cash Transfer: A systematic review of 201 studies on cash transfers (conditional and unconditional) published between 2000 and 2015
Relevance: Economic, Health, Employment, Educational Effects. Effects of varying durations and amounts of cash transfers.

Paper: H. Bewley, A. Bryson, J. Forth.  Small and Medium-sized Enterprises: Findings from the 2004 Workplace Employment Relations Survey. National Institute for Economic and Social Research and Policy Studies Institute. 2014.
Summary of findings: In Great Britain, employees at small firms are more likely to believe that they have job autonomy, influence, security a greater degree of influence over the final decisions made by managers, as well as a higher level of general well-being than employees working for larger firms.
Useful Tools: Variables and measures of employee well-being and workplace relations
Relevance: Effects on workplace relations and employee-well being in SMEs

Paper: John W. Budd. Worker Well-being and the Importance of Work: Bridging the Gap. European Journal of Industrial Relations. 2015.
Summary of findings: Worker well-being is optimized when an individual’s work matches their skill set, allows freedom of self-determination, and offers opportunities for challenge and initiative.
Relevance: Psychological Effects

Paper: J. Costello, A. Erkanli, W. Copeland. Association of Family Income Supplements in Adolescence With Development of Psychiatric and Substance Use Disorders in Adulthood Among an American Indian Population.  Journal of the American Medical Association. May 2010.
Summary of findings: Lower prevalence of psychopathology in American Indian youth following a family income supplement persisted into adulthood. The effect was strongest for alcohol and cannabis abuse, dependence, or both, and was specific to the youngest cohort.
Relevance: Psychological Effects

Paper: A. Clark, A. Oswald. Satisfaction and comparison income. Journal of Public Economics. September 1996.
Summary of findings: In Great Britain, workers' reported satisfaction levels are inversely related to their comparison wage rates, and strongly declining in the level of education.
Relevance: Psychological Effects

Paper: A. Ferrer-i-Carbonell. Income and well-being: an empirical analysis of the comparison income effect. Journal of Public Economics. September 2004.
Summary of findings: In West Germany, one's own income is about as important as the income of others (a reference group) for individual happiness. Individuals are happier the larger their income is in comparison with the income of the reference group, although this comparison effect is asymmetric.
Relevance: Psychological and Social (comparative income) Effects

Paper: G. W. Imbens, D. B. Rubin, B. I. Sacerdote. Estimating the effect of unearned income on labor earnings, savings, and consumption: Evidence from a survey of lottery players. American Economic Review, 91(4), 778–794. 2001.
Summary of findings: Unearned income reduces labor earnings, with a marginal propensity to consume leisure of approximately 11 percent, and with larger effects for individuals between 55 and 65 years old. The savings rate for unearned income is about 16 percent for those who received half their income and increases with the proportion of the income received.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Lottery prizes won by people playing the lottery in Massachusetts in the 1980s
Relevance: Economic Effects

Paper: Andrew K. MacLeod, Clare Conway. Well-being and the Anticipation of Future Positive Experiences: The Role of Income, Social Networks, and Planning Ability. Cognition and Emotion. 2012.
Summary of findings: Subjective well-being increases with the number of anticipated positive experiences, which in turn increases with the size of one's social network, the number of steps in plans to achieve goals, and the size of household income.
Useful Tools: Temporal Satisfaction with Life Scale, Exchange Approach Scale, Positive and Negative Affect Scale
Relevance: Psychological Effects. Expectations of future positive effects.

Paper: R. Maynard, R .Murnane. The Effects of a Negative Income Tax on School Performance: Results of an Experiment. The Journal of Human Resources, 14(4), 463-476. 1979.
Summary of findings: A negative income tax led to an increase in the average reading achievement of children in grades 4 through 6, but did not have any observable beneficial effects for older children.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Negative Income Tax
Relevance: Educational Effects

Paper: J Riccio & C. Miller. New York City’s First Conditional Cash Transfer Program: What Worked, What Didn’t (Executive Summary). MDRC. 2016.
Summary of findings: Conditional cash transfers reduced financial hardship, increased graduation rates for reading-proficient 9th graders who entered high school, and increased households' use of preventive dental services. It did not affect school outcomes for elementary and middle school students, the use of preventive medical services, and parents’ employment in or earnings from jobs covered by the unemployment insurance system.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Families received over $8700 on average over a three-year period.
Relevance: Economic, Educational, Health Employment Effects

Paper: K. P. Robins. A Comparison of the Labor Supply Findings from the Four Negative Income Tax Experiments. The Journal of Human Resources. 1985.
Summary of findings: A negative income tax led to a fall in labor supply by about the equivalent of two weeks of full-time employment for husbands, three weeks for wives and single female heads, and four weeks for youth.
Nature of Cash Transfer: A study of four NIT experiments sponsored by the US federal government.
Relevance: Labor Supply Effects

Paper: P. Schulz. Universal Basic Income in a Feminist Perspective and Gender Analysis. Global Social Policy: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Public Policy and Social Development, vol. 17, no. 1, 2017, pp. 89–92. January 2017.
Summary of findings: A universal basic income can help to combat historical structural inequalities inherited by modern women by freeing women-led households from the vulnerability of poverty and subsequent marginalization. It can also help balance unequal power relationships with male relatives and partners.
Nature of Cash Transfer: UBI
Relevance: Gender Effects

Paper: B. Wanrooy, H. Bewley, A. Bryson, J. Forth, S. Freeth, L. Stokes, S. Wood. The 2011 Workplace Employment Relations Study. Economic and Social Research Council, Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service, and National Institute of Economic and Social Research.
Summary of findings: This document reports the results of a large scale study conducted in 2011 by the UK government on employee relations, and covers the experiences of workplaces and their workforces in the 2008-09 economic recession, the structures and practices of employment relations and the experiences of workers
Useful Tools: Variables, measures, survey and interview guides for measuring employee well-being
Relevance: Effects on work experience

Paper: Smith, V., & Halpin, B. (2014). Low-wage work uncertainty often traps low-wage workers. Policy Brief, (9).
Summary of findings: Since low-wage employment limit workers' ability to learn new skills and search for better jobs, raising the minimum wage or introducing living wages can allow workers to support their households on full-time work, freeing up time to develop their human capital.
Relevance: Work-life conflict, labor-leisure decision

Paper: Asfaw, S., Davis, B., Dewbre, J., Handa, S., & Winters, P. (2014). Cash transfer programme, productive activities and labour supply: evidence from a randomised experiment in Kenya. The journal of development studies, 50(8), 1172-1196.
Summary of findings: Kenya's Cash Transfer for Orphans and Vulnerable Children Programme increased food consumption coming from home production, accumulation of productive assets, and formation of non-farm enterprise, especially amongst females. It provided more flexibility to families in terms of labor allocation decisions, and reduced child labor, especially for boys. However, it had little impact on crop production.
Nature of Cash Transfer: A flat monthly transfer of Ksh1500 to ultra-poor families with orphans and vulnerable children aged 17 years and younger.
Relevance: Health, Employment Effects

Paper: Banerjee, A. V., Hanna, R., Kreindler, G. E., & Olken, B. A. (2017). Debunking the stereotype of the lazy welfare recipient: Evidence from cash transfer programs. The World Bank Research Observer, 32(2), 155-184.
Summary of findings: Cash transfer programs have no observable impact on one's propensity to work or the overall number of hours worked for both men and women.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Data collated from seven CT/UCT/In-kind transfer studies
Countries involved: Honduras, Indonesia, Morocco, Mexico Nicaragua, the Philippines
Relevance: Effect of transfer programs on work incentives

Paper: Ardington, C., Case, A., & Hosegood, V. (2009). Labor supply responses to large social transfers: Longitudinal evidence from South Africa. American economic journal: Applied economics, 1(1), 22-48.
Summary of findings: Large cash transfers to the elderly lead to increased employment amongst prime-aged adults through labor migration. A pension increases household resources which can be used to stake migrants until they become self-sufficient, and implies that a pensioner is around to care for small children while prime-aged adults look for work.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Cash Transfers
Relevance: Employment Effects

Paper: Ugo Colombino. Is Unconditional Basic Income a Viable Alternative to Other Social Welfare Measures? IZA World of Labor. 2015.
Summary of findings: An unconditional basic income can redistribute the gains from automation and globalization, build a buffer against shocks and systemic risks, and generate positive labor supply incentives amongst the poor. While it is simple, transparent, and has low administration costs, financing it likely requires higher taxes, hence tax systems need to be carefully designed to avoid canceling the potential benefits of unconditional basic income through efficiency losses.
Nature of Cash Transfer: UBI
Relevance: Political and Economic Feasibility

Paper: K. Widerquist. A failure to communicate: What (if anything) can we learn from the negative income tax experiments? Journal of Socioeconomics, 34(1), 49-81. 2005.
Summary of findings: Labor market effects of negative income tax experiments are often overstated and misinterpreted, since without an estimate of the labor market demand response, researchers cannot estimate the overall market response.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Five NIT experiments in Canada and the U.S. from 1969 to 1980.
Relevance: Employment Effects, Media and Political spin on experiment results, NIT experiment assumptions

Paper: A. Randall, E. Simeonova, W. Copeland, A. Angold, E. J. Costello. Young Adult Obesity and Household Income: Effects of Unconditional Cash Transfers. American Economic Journal: Applied Economics. April 2013.
Summary of findings: Household cash transfers lead to a larger increase in weight for children from the initially poorest households relative to those from richer households, and this is not due to initial health conditions.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Cash transfers
Relevance: Health Effects

Paper: Blattman, C., & Dercon, S. (2017). The impacts of industrial and entrepreneurial work on income and health: Experimental evidence from Ethiopia.
Summary of findings: Workers offered industrial jobs did not earn higher wages, but faced riskier health conditions, and often quit their jobs. In contrast, wages of participants in an entrepreneurship program are higher, and fewer participants switched to taking on an industrial job.
Relevance: Sampling Design

Paper: M. Nikiforos, M. Steinbaum, G. Zezza. Modeling the Macroeconomic Effects of a Universal Basic Income. Roosevelt Institute. August 2017.
Summary of findings: Based on the Levy Institute macroeconomic model, enacting a UBI and paying for it by increasing the federal debt would grow the economy. When paying for the policy by increasing taxes, the distributional effects of UBI causes the economy to grow.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Three versions of UBI:  $1,000 a month to all adults, $500 a month to all adults, and a $250 a month child allowance
Relevance: Macroeconomic effects of a UBI based on the Levy Institute macroeconomic model

Paper: J. Cunha. Testing Paternalism: Cash versus In-Kind Transfers. American Economic Journal: Applied Economics 2014, 6(2): 195–230. 2014
Summary of findings: In-kind food transfers implemented to promote better nutrition did not lead to meaningful differential improvements in overall consumption and health outcomes as compared to the provision of cash transfers, as the cash was largely spent on nutritious food as well.
Nature of Cash Transfer: In kind transfer of 10 food items providing a balanced diet worth 205 pesos vs a cash transfer of 150 pesos
Relevance: Comparing paternalistic in-kind transfers with cash transfers

Paper: I. Marinescu. No Strings Attached: The Behavioral Effects of U.S. Unconditional Cash Transfer Programs. Roosevelt Institute. May 2017.
Summary of findings: A review of the empirical results from a variety of studies on unconditional cash transfer programs showed that there is usually no impact on or a moderate decrease in labor participation and they usually lead to a significant increase in other quality-of-life benefits, such as mental and physical health, educational outcomes, parenting, and reduced criminal activity.
Relevance: General economic impact of unconditional cash transfers

Paper: Damon Jones, Ioana Elena Marinescu. The Labor Market Impacts of Universal and Permanent Cash Transfers: Evidence from the Alaska Permanent Fund. SSRN. February 2018.
Summary of findings: A universal and permanent cash transfer does not significantly decrease aggregate employment.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Yearly cash dividened from the Alaska Permanent Fund
Relevance: Employment effects

Paper: Randall Akee, William E. Copeland, Gordon Keeler, Elizabeth Jane Costello. Parents' Incomes and Children's Outcomes: A Quasi-Experiment Using Transfer Payments from Casino Profits. American Economic Journal Applied Economics. January 2010.
Summary of findings: An regular unconditional cash transfer led to children having higher levels of education in their young adulthood and a lower incidence of criminality for minor offenses, likely via improved parental quality.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Unconditional cash transfers on a six-months basis
Relevance: Effects on children via parental quality

Paper: Adriana D. Kugler, Ingrid Rojas. Do CCTs Improve Employment and Earnings in the Very Long-Term? Evidence from Mexico. NBER Working Paper No. 24248. January 2018
Summary of findings: Kugler and Rojas assess the effect of the exposure to PROSPERA on three education variables: educational attainment, high school education and at least one year of tertiary education, and five employment variables: probability of being employed, the number of hours worked per week, employment quality,likelihood of having an employment contract, the likelihood of having non-wage benefits, and hourly wages. After controlling for multiple hypothesis testing, the authors find significant and positive effects in all cases. The positive effects are however, weaker for women and children of illiterate women
Nature of Cash Transfer: PROSPERA program

Paper: Johannes Haushofer, Jeremy Shapiro. The Long-term Impact Of Unconditional Cash Transfers: Experimental Evidence From Kenya. January 2018.
Summary of findings: Using a two stage randomization design, Haushofer and Shapiro assess the economic and psychological outcomes three years after the beginning of the Give Directly cash transfer program in 2011. The authors report  higher levels of asset holdings, consumption, food security and psychological well-being relative to non-recipients in the same village. They also note spillover effects, wherein households affected by the spillovers have lower consumption and food security than pure control households.

Paper: Amanda Y. Agan, Michael D. Makowsky. The Minimum Wage, EITC, and Criminal Recidivism. SSRN. February 2018.
Summary of findings: Using administrative prison release records released between 2000 and 2014, Agan and Makowsky use a difference-indifferences strategy to identify the effect of  state and federal minimum wage increases, and EITC on recidivism. In their analysis on EITC, the availability of state top-ups to the federal EITC is associated with a 1.6 percentage point lower rate of recidivism amongst women, while having no significant effect on men.

Paper: Djavad Salehi-Isfahani, Mohammad H. Mostafavi-Dehzooei. Cash transfers and labor supply: evidence from a large-scale program in Iran. October 2017.
Summary of findings:
Salehi-Isfahani and Mostafavi-Dehzooei study the effects of large scale cash transfer program in Iran which distributed a fixed amount (amounting to 29% of the median per capita household income) of
cash to all Iranians (with a 95% take-up). Using panel data and a difference-in-difference model, no evidence that cash transfers reduced labor supply, except among the youth (20-29 years) where they find a negative effect. They also find that service sector workers increased their hours of work.

Paper: Angelucci, Manuela et al. Consumption Smoothing and Economic Behavior in the Presence of Expected and Unexpected Shocks. August 2017
Summary of findings: An unexpected negative shock in income reduces labor supply, food security, mental health and healthful behavior but does not affect parenting, cognition, risk and time preferences, and aspirations about childrens' educational attainment. On the other hand, an expected positive shock caused by a conditional cash transfer does not lead to any change in the outcomes apart from increasing disposable income.
Relevance: Effects of CCTs framed as expected income shocks

Paper: Bazzi, Samuel A et al. It’s All in the Timing: Cash Transfers and Consumption Smoothing in a Developing Country. Journal of Economic Behavior & Organization, 119, N1172-119. November 2015.
Summary of findings: Timely receipt of cash transfers do not yield expenditure changes relative to non-recipients, while delayed receipt reduces expenditures by 7.5%, giving evidence that the impact of cash transfers depends on the timing of transfers.
Relevance: How timing of cash transfers affect consumption

Paper: Annie McEwen, Jennifer Stewart. The Relationship Between Income and Children’s Outcomes: A Synthesis of Canadian Evidence. CRDCN Synthesis Series. April 2014.
Summary of findings: A large degree of the correlation between lower income and worse child outcomes (social, cognitive, behavioral, emotional) can be explained by factors usually associated with a lower income. A household's income itself has a relatively small influence on child outcomes after considering other factors. This suggests that raising a poor household's income alone may not have a sizeable impact on children outcomes.
Relevance: Effects of income on child education

Paper: David Calnitsky Jonathan P. Latner. Basic Income in a Small Town: Understanding the Elusive Effects on Work. Social Problems. March 2017.
Summary of findings: Calnitsky and Latner analyze the labor market effects of the Manitoba Basic Annual Income Experiment (1975-77) and report moderately sized basic income generated an 11.3 percentage point reduction in labor market participation, however this was largely driven by young and single-member hoursehold participants. They also note 30% of this reduction can be attributed to “social interaction” or “community context” effects.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Cash transfers: $19500 - half of family's income.
Relevance: Effects of UBI on the labor market

Paper: Anna Aizer, Shari Eli, Joseph P. Ferrie, Adriana Lleras-Muney. The Long Term Impact of Cash Transfers to Poor Families. NBER. May 2014.
Summary of findings: Male children of successful applicants to the Mother's Pension program lived one year longer, received one-third more years of schooling, were less likely to be underweight, and had higher income in adulthood compared to those of rejected mothers.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Mother's Pension Program: Monthly transfers which represented about 12-25% of household income. $10.00 to $35.00 for the first child, increasing non-linearly with the number of children
Relevance: Long-term outcome of a household cash transfer program on children (hence a proxy to the long-run impact of a UBI)

Paper: Hoyt Bleakley, Joseph P. Ferrie. Up from Poverty? The 1832 Cherokee Land Lottery and the Long-run Distribution of Wealth. NBER. August 2013.
Summary of findings: In the 1832 Cherokee Land Lottery where winners were randomly selected, the authors found that winners are on average richer in the long-run but this is due to a shifting of mass from the middle to the upper tail of the wealth distribution, while the lower tail remains unaffected, hence exacerbating inequality.
Nature of Cash Transfer: Land transfers (can be cashed out immediately)
Relevance: Long-term outcome of an increase in wealth (hence a proxy to the long-run impact of a UBI)

Paper: Added from July 09 onwards

Baird, Sarah Jane; Mckenzie, David J.; Ozler, Berk. The effects of cash transfers on adult labor market outcomes (English). Policy Research working paper; no. WPS 8404. Washington, D.C. : World Bank Group. 2018.
Summary of findings: Noting that there are several potential channels via which a cash transfer program can affect labor supply apart from the standard income effect, Baird et al (2018) review a range of studies on conditional and unconditional cash transfers. They conclude that unconditional cash transfer programs, cash transfer programs with conditions unrelated to employment and remittances tend to have limited to no impact on adult labor. On the other hand, cash transfers for job search assistance and small business start-up usually increase labor supply likely by alleviating liquidity and risk constraints, although the effects via these channels cannot be isolated from those due to increases in human capital as well as other general equilibrium effects.
Relevance: Variation in the impact of cash transfer programs on employment outcomes

Paper: Baird, Sarah Jane; Mcintosh, Craig; Ozler, Berk. When the money runs out : do cash transfers have sustained effects on human capital accumulation ? (English). Policy Research working paper; no. WPS 7901; Impact Evaluation series; Paper is funded by the Knowledge for Change Program (KCP). Washington, D.C. : World Bank Group. 2016.
Summary of findings: Baird et al (2018) investigates the medium-term effects of a two-year, two-treatment arms cash transfer program to adolescent females in Malawi, where one treated grouped received cash transfers conditional upon school attendance while the other received equal-sized unconditional cash transfers. They found that while unconditional cash transfers led to reduced teen marriages, live births and HIV infections as well as improvements in psychological wellbeing at the end of the program, these effects were not sustained two years after. Their husbands had relatively lower cognitive ability, although their children born during the program had improved HAZ scores. On the other hand, girls receiving conditional cash transfers saw sustained positive effects on school attainment, teenage marriage and pregnancy incidences, and desired fertility. They are also more likely to be matched with husbands who have completed secondary school. There are however no gains in other outcomes such as earnings, consumption, health, empowerment and subjective well-being.
Relevance: Variation in the impact of cash transfer program on outcomes for females

Paper: Randall Akee, William E. Copeland, Emilia Simeonova, Elizabeth Jane Costello. How Does Household Income Affect Child Personality Traits and Behaviors? American Economic Review, 108(3), 775-827. March 2018.
Summary of findings: Akee et al (2018) examine the effects of a cash transfers from the distribution of casino profits amongst adult Eastern Cherookee tribe members on child development. They use data from the Great Smoky Mountains Study of Youth to assess the mental health and well-being in children. They find that an increase in unearned household income led to large positive effects on children’s emotional and behavioral health and positive personality trait development, especially amongst children who did not do as well as their peers in these aspects prior to the treatment. They also find that improved parental behavior and familial relationships was likely to be an important channel via which financial well-being may impact child development.
Relevance: Impact of improved financial well-being on child development

Paper:
Jessica Wiederspan, Elizabeth Rhodes & H. Luke Shaefer. Expanding
the Discourse on Antipoverty Policy: Reconsidering a Negative Income Tax. Journal of Poverty. 2015.
Summary of findings: Wiederspan et al argue that a negative income tax can help fill the gaps in current federal means-tested assistance programs which tend not to be sufficiently large and far-reaching. While past NIT experiments have led to a reduction in labor supply, the effects were not as large as often speculated, and time saved from work was spent on childcare and looking for work. Moreover, those experiments do not measure long-term, general equilibrium effects. They then show that an NIT can be funded using expenditure from existing programs which it potentially replaces, and if the marginal tax rate was chosen carefully. Finally, they assert that a NIT can be made more politically appeasing by appealing to the fact that it coheres with people’s values rather than focusing on the technical policy details, as well as by highlighting the economic and social costs of poverty to society.
Relevance: Presenting the case for implementing a negative income tax - some arguments are applicable to a UBI

Paper: Sidhya additions
Walker, Michael. Informal  Taxation  and  Cash  Transfers:  Experimental  Evidence from  Kenya. Job Market Paper. December 2017.
Summary of findings: Walker (2017) estimates the effect of exogenous positive income shocks to household income in Kenya on informal taxes and provision of public goods. Using surveys of village leaders, and panel and experimental household data from a sample of participants who received a large one-time unconditional cash transfer in GiveDirectly’s RCT, Walker estimates regression models at household, village and sub-location level and reports no  significant  effects  on  the  amount  paid  in  formal  taxes,  and in the  informal  tax  rate. He notes a 2.4 percentage point increase in county  tax  payment  which he relates to the fact that  recipient  households  are  more  likely  to  be  self-employed. There is also no attributable effect on public goods provision or the quality of public good provision, indicating no short run effects of the income changes on public good provision or informal taxation systems that can be attributable to the exogenous income shock.

Paper: Taylor, Edward J.; Kagin, Justin; Filipski, Mateusz; Thome, Karen. Evaluating general equilibrium impacts of Kenya’s cash transfer programme for orphans and vulnerable children (CT-OVC). Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations. 2013.
Summary of findings: Taylor et al examine the general equilibrium effects of a cash transfer for orphans and vulnerable children (CT-OVC) in Kenya. Using four administrative and private data sources, they simulate the estimates of income multipliers and highlight significant spillover effects of the CT-OVC transfers in local economies. Local income multipliers are significantly greater than 1 in nominal terms, even when capital and labor constraints limit the local supply response. They note most of the effects are among ineligible households, indicating that the programme enables them to access more capital and labor to increase their production to respond to increased local demand. They note variations in impacts across regions in the income multiplier, and highlight differences in capital, liquidity and labor market constraints.

Paper: Evans, David; Popova, Anna. Cash Transfers and Temptation Goods: A Review of Global Evidence. Policy Research Working Paper 6886. The World Bank. 2013
Summary of findings: Evans and Popova review 44 estimates from 19 studies on conditional and unconditional cash transfers in low and middle income countries from 1997-2014 and find with almost no expections that the reviewed studies found either an insignificant effect or a significant negative effect of cash transfers on temptation goods, which they define as expenditures on alcohol and tobacco. When they diffrentiate only the estimates from studies which had a randomized design, no estimate was reported to show a positive and signitifant effect on expenditures on temptation goods.

Paper: Department for International Development, UK. Cash Transfers: Evidence Paper. Policy Report. 2011
Summary of findings: In their evidence paper, DfID reports that there is substantial evidence to show that cash transfers can reduce inquality, boost movement out of poverty for working age populations, and has led to sizable gains in access to health and education indicators, but have had lesser success in the final outcomes from these two sectors.They also report indicative and deterministic factors that indiciate that cash transfers can improve household productivity, income generation, female equality, empowerment of the poor and local market development. They also report that there is little evidence of negative labor market effects and negative effects on fertility.  While there is limited evidence on aggregate growth, they indicate that cash transfers can lead to long term growth through improvements in human capital.

Paper: Ravaillon, Martin. Guaranteed Employment or Guaranteed Income? Working Paper 482. Center for Global Development. 2018.
Summary of findings: Ravaillon critically reviews the two rights-based policies of guaranteed income and guaranteed work from a policy perspective. With a specific case study of India to highlight constraints and challenges in implementing these policies in developing countrie, Ravaillon argues that issues of cost, targetting, corruption and variations in contexts and settings are only a few of the features which restrict an unequivocal support of either policy. He argues that finely targetting transfers like UCTs and CCTs and untargeted universal transfers like UBI may be preferrable in different settings, but policies which don't target too finely may be more cost-effective in combatting poverty in some settings.

Paper: Additions (Gary)
Jacob Bastian and Katherine Michelmore. The Long-Term Impact of the Earned Income Tax Credit on Children’s Education and Employment Outcomes. Journal of Labor Economics. July 2018.
Summary of findings: Bastian and Michelmore examine the long-run impact of an EITC on children who were exposed to EITC variations by using EITC exposure as an instrument for family income. They used data from the 1968 to 2013 waves of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics which captures four decades of variation in EITC. They find that an exogenous shock in income induced by a change in EITC policy increase educational attainment and employment in adulthood, and this is done through increasing pre-tax income. Their reduced-form estimate suggest that an increase of $1000 in EITC exposure increases high school graduation and college graduation by 1.3% and 4.2% respectively for children exposed to the increase when they were between the ages of 13 to 18. It also raises the probability of them being employed by 1.0%. However, EITC exposure had no significant effects on children below the age of 13 conditional upon later exposure.

Paper: Hilary Hoynes, Jesse Rothstein, and Krista Ruffini. Making Work Pay Better Through an Expanded Earned Income Tax Credit. The Hamilton Project. October 2017.
Summary of findings: The EITC has been found to reduce poverty rates as well as improve health and education outcomes. However, for families with two or less children, the maximum credit distributed to them has remained the same in inflation-adjusted terms since 1996. As such, Hoynes et al propose to increase the EITC credit by 10% while maintaining its current structure so as to increase wages which have been stagnating, increase employment further and bring about 600,000 people out of poverty.

Paper:
Handa, S., L. Natali, D. Seidenfeld, G. Tembo and B. Davis. Can Unconditional Cash Transfers
Lead to Sustainable Poverty Reduction? Evidence from two government-led programmes in
Zambia. Innocenti Working Paper 2016-21, UNICEF Office of Research, Florence. 2016.
Summary of findings: From 2010 to 2011, the Zambian government launched two unconditional cash transfer pilot programmes. The Child Grant Program (CGP) targeted all households with a child whose age is under three in year 2011 in three poor rural districts, and the Multiple Category Targeted Programme (MCP) was implemented in two rural districts and targeted households with a female or elderly head keeping orphans, or a disabled member, or deemed to be critically vulnerable otherwise. Bimonthly transfers were made to each household irrespective of size, and this entailed a transfer of USD 24 per month in Purchasing Power Parity terms. ITT estimates made 24 months and 36 months into the study in nine domains, namely total consumption, food security, asset holdings, subjective well-being (relative poverty), income and revenues, finance and debt, material needs, schooling and young child anthropometry, show that that both the CGP and the MCP had statistically significant effects in almost all domains except for schooling and young child anthropometry for the CGP, and incomes and revenues after 24 months for the MCP (effects on young child nutrition were not measured for the MCP). A sizeable multiplier effect is observed given that households spent 59 per cent more than the value of the transfer.
